posts.cooked: Seeing as we have a lower weight limit this season…what is everybody’s favorite lightening design?

Thanks for your input, Focusing on a smaller robot can definitely help stay within the weight limit. Any tips or examples of specific designs or materials that have worked well for keeping things light while maintaining durability

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Thinner materials win over pocketing material out. It is also generally cheaper and faster…

A lot of bearings out there can be bushings instead.

3d printing can be REALLY strong and lightweight.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Skyehawk:

Thinner materials

Perfect example there are various wall thicknesses available for 1x1 and 2x1 extrusions. Thicker wall may be better for lower areas and where you expect impacts, but use thinner wall on arms and portions that are higher up. This keeps the cog lower overall.

Removing unnecessary materials. 1/8th boxtube, .25 plate, or plates with excessively large outer dimensions are extremely heavy, but not really getting you any strength. For that matter, 1/8th boxtube isn’t even even stronger when pocketed to a similar weight of 1/16th , and doesn’t even double your strength in many cases, however analysis on alternate boundary conditions (mainly clamped between gussets) should be looked at. Avoiding bending in the first place will give you so much more than double the strength that doubling might as well be zero improvment. The outsides of plates are the easiest to cut, as they do literally nothing.

Apart from that, you can generally pocket plates by just connecting the points of interest  (screws, bearings, contact), and removing everything else. Use large radii on the fillets to avoid stress risers. Boxtube should almost never be pocketed, as apart from in highly-controlled loading scenarios, you are weakening the boxtube.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Does lightening on 1/16" extrusion make it too weak or is it a viable strategy? I’m hoping to reduce elevator weight as much as possible and I was wondering if the lightening on it would be too much.

Generally no. When you put holes in an elevator, you severely weaken it in bending in the bending director with moments normal to the holes by splitting one beam into two beams with barely any 2nd moment area due to moving the centroid right next to most of the material. You also get stress risers to make the beam another several times weaker on top of that.

Or in less words, putting in holes makes the beam super weak in 1 direction. Because you don’t get to choose how another robot causes your elevator to get it, it won’t go well. And this is disregarding the localized effects that bearings have on the tube if there isn’t enough material to make localized bending not a concern.

In the rare case you have perfectly unidirectional bending, you can slot the beam with large radii in the other direction, as long as you stay sufficiently far from the base of the beam as the highest stresses are at the base. In this scenario, avoid making the slots longer tuan a few inches to avoid some weird buckling modes that would cause early failure.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Would a basic 10-32 hole pattern be ok or should we essentially only have holes where necessary?

I have not looked at that specific interaction closely, but I don’t imagine it being problematic unless you put other stress risers near the holes, as holes in the middle of the beam are no worse than the ones used to mount in many cases.

posts.name: Leo
posts.cooked:
A basic 10-32 hole pattern (.5 inch spacing, 3 holes across 2x1) works great for taking some weight off of boxtube, while also allowing for really easy mounting of new gussets/parts. It doesn’t really affect the strength of the tube, so it go anywhere on a robot (even elevators or drivetrains). example_pattern 836×318 38.2 KB
